captions.text: (upbeat music)
- I am so hot right now.
I'm like really overheated,
I'm not sure if I'm talking fast,
I can't tell.
- I'm fidgeting.
I'm wringing my hands,
which I don't think I was doing before.
I'm also talking faster.
I can tell that I'm talking faster.
I can tell that I'm thinking faster.

- I can't stop moving
and typing really fast.

- It's like the end of the
night when you're drinking,
you're like, "I'm still hyper
"cause I still got alcohol in me
"but I'm probably gonna fall asleep
"in the middle of the street."
- So I'm still amped up,
but not in a good way.

I think that I'm feeling
a little more energetic
than earlier but I don't know.
- I actually feel better than yesterday.
Monster hit me super fast
and then I was kind of like crazy.
I'm just kinda going.
Not too hyper, but not tired.
- Whatever sort of uptick that I was on
I'm on the other side now.
- It's been like a slower build.
It's been like this.
You know, rather than...

- I'm having a hard
time sitting at my seat.

Like staying at my seat
and getting my work done.
I think this might be a good drink
if I was gonna like go out and...
I don't know.
Skateboard or something.
- I'm feeling kinda tired right now
'cause the adrenaline is going down,
but when I am focusing on something,
I'm really focused.
I can get it all done.
I can multi-task which is nice.

But I'm wondering by now
if it's psychological.
Definitely feel both more scatterbrained
and forgetful than I normally am.
- I don't know.
I feel lethargic.

comments.text:
+Cameron24529 Pharmacy student here. They contain caffeine (usually at a 
concentration of 0.03g/100 mL which is relatively high) to inhibit the 
adenosine a2 receptor in the brain, responsible for feelings of tiredness. 
So when the receptor causing the tiredness is blocked, this leads to 
increased attentiveness and concentration. Depending on the amount of 
caffeine in the energy drink and the quality of the caffeine, they work. 
Unless you have consumed so much caffeine in your life that you are immune 
to their effects.

comments.text:
The problem with this way of testing is that the people know what they are 
drinking and can therefore have a bias thinking of which energy drink can 
be better before the testing even began. The data recorded for this 
experiment would have been more credible if the subjects were not told what 
the drink was or what the observers were testing for exactly; this way it 
would minimize a bias of what energy drink performs better. The bias is 
minimized since no one know what they drank, and no one knows what to 
expect later in the day. I did enjoy the video though :)﻿

comments.text:
A general energy drink deconstructed:

A.  Water + Simple Carbohydrate's (Sugar/High Fructose Corn Syrup)
This will hit your stomach, and go into the intestines where is absorbed, 
and the sugar is rapidly processed into the blood stream with various 
ratio's of glucose to fructose or no ratio, but typically with a higher 
Fructose to Glucose   ratio. This means that the sugar can get into your 
cells extremely fast. The rapid dumping into the blood stream will   first 
shock the pancreas to spike insulin to deal with a bolus of glucose.  The 
fructose will directly enter cells without   any need for the presence of 
insulin.  This effect results in a good energy source following the next 
effects. 

B.  Caffeine
This enters the blood and stimulates the release of Serotonin which then 
triggers Dopamine which promotes a sense   of excitement, and mood 
enhancement.  The caffeine artificially stimulates the Adrenal glands to 
release Cortisol and   Epinephrine. This results in further blood sugar 
release into the blood, increased heart rate, increased blood pressure, 
pupil constriction, massive increases in ATP production, shutting off of 
parts of the gastrointestinal system, increased stomach acid production 
(Problematic for people who have GERD or Heartburn) and blood shunting to 
all vital organs including the brain, and most importantly the muscles. 
This effect provides a person with the sense that   they are strong, ready 
to go, and could get a million things done.  For some people this effect is 
so strong, they may feel as if they could just keep going for days.  There 
is other stuff, but these are some of the main things. 

C.  B-Vitamins
This has numerous functions in the body including proper red blood cell 
development, and nerve function. Given that your muscles are dependent on 
good nerve firing, B-Vitamins help with the excitability of the motor 
neurons.  Although it's questionable how effective they are given the dose, 
and time needed to really get any benefit out of it. So you could properly 
say it's not that necessary in energy drinks. Niacin can also provide a 
flushing effect in some people but typically energy drinks use a form that 
does not cause this effect. 

D.  Herbs/Amino Acids:  (Ginseng, L- Arginine) 
Depending on what energy drink you get, some have various herbs or isolated 
amino acids added which in theory help with the mental alertness, recovery, 
or energy boost. The problem is that credible research has not been done to 
show that what they are adding actually is doing what they are saying it 
does. It has been found that numerous supplements that were put on the 
market in recent years did not even contain the primary ingredient they 
were claiming to sell you.  So it should make you wonder if your even 
getting anything at all. Furthermore, you have no idea of the quality, 
concentration, or how long it can stay in the can before it's properties 
are even effective.  So this whole part of an energy drink seems more 
gimmicky if anything. It's not to say it can't work, but unlikely. 

This is in summary the basic formulation to every energy drink alongside 
some artificial flavors, other vitamins and perhaps some minerals. The 
ingredients are dirt cheap, and the formulation is simple. This is why they 
can market it so cheap. The star ingredients is simply caffeine and sugar. 



How come I energy drinks don't work for me anymore? 

For any person drinking an energy drink for the first time, your response 
should follow a standard pattern.  At first you feel amazing, and with 
continued use they will become increasingly less effective.  The more you 
drink them, the less they do for you each time around.

The problem is that Caffeine is mimicking a hormone called Adenosine. 
 Adenosine binds to Adenosine receptor sites on motor neurons and other 
nerve cells which in turn tells the cells to slow down in excitability. 
This is important because it helps you stay composed throughout the day, 
and helps you understand when it's time to go to bed.  Over the coarse of 
the day, Adenosine production is increased like clock work and this makes 
you more and more tired.  

Caffeine hi-jacks these receptor sites and stops Adenosine from working. 
 This then causes the nerve cells to become increasingly excited as if 
there is no brakes to tell it to slow down.  This rapid firing then prompts 
a stress like response which stimulates your adrenals to activate, 
prompting the entire response with your Adrenal Glands releasing 
Cortisol+Epinephrine. 

With caffeine blocking the Adensosine receptor sites, the body detects that 
Adenosine is not doing it's job, and increases it's production and release. 
 This effect results in large amounts of Adenosine building up, and after 
caffeine begins to break down, you are bombarded with Adenosine which 
rapidly slows down nerve firing.  This is partly why you have such a sudden 
CRASH and feel tired.  The rapid sugar high also has a hand in prompting a 
crash FYI.

Over time with frequent caffeine usage, the body will increase Adenosine 
receptor sites, and by doing this it means that Adenosine can compete with 
Caffeine and bind, where previously it was unable to.  By doing this, it 
negates the effects of caffeine and the effect of caffeine stops working. 
 The only solution to get around this problem is to increase your intake of 
caffeine.  

This is why you have people walking around that drink large amounts of 
caffeine and it does nothing for them... this entire process has gone on, 
and their body no longer functions how it used to.  

If your one of those people that has never drank caffeine, and do not 
respond to caffeine, then it's possible to say that your one of the small 
few that may present features not typical in the structure of your brain or 
body in general.  The possible answers to this will be for another day. 
 This is already an ESSAY!  FUCK. Caffeine did it again. ﻿

comments.text:
Science fact: there are appropriate psychological arousal levels for 
different activities. For focused tasks like driving it is common sense to 
know that you would do bad if your arousal levels are low (because you're 
tired/sleepy). In the same way you would do bad if your energy levels are 
too high so that you cannot keep still and focus. So generally energy 
drinks help you for more mechanical things that do not require a lot of 
thinking and attention. The 5-hour drink improved scores because it gives 
you a lower, more steady energy rush than others. ﻿

their information and made quantitative and qualitative observations, but 
where was the hypothesis? Maybe genders react differently? They only tested

didn't take into account exercise, any dieting that their test subjects may 
be on, along with their food schedules and habits, caffeine tolerance, 
their sleep... uh! It aggravates me how much they leave out.
